Fig. 1 (a) In-situ XRD patterns and (b) in-situ Raman spectra of the as-synthesized Na/FeZn catalyst during exposure in Ar at 298 K and H2 at 623 K; (c) TEM images and particle size distribution, (d) HRTEM image, (e) HAADF-STEM image, and EDX elemental maps of (f) Fe, (g) Zn, (h) Na, and (i) O of the as-synthesized Na/FeZn catalyst. Fig. 2 Effects of H2 (a and b; 187.5 kPa CO2 and 140–750 kPa H2), CO2 (c and d; 562.5 kPa H2, 93.75–225 kPa CO2), CO (e and f; 93.75–187.5 kPa CO2, 0–150 kPa CO, and 562.5–900 kPa H2) on the formation rates of C2+ hydrocarbons (a, c, and e) and C2+ olefins (b, d, and f) during CO2 -CO-H2 reactions (593 K, 300000 cm3 gcat −1 h−1, 1500 kPa total pressure) over the Na/FeZn catalyst. Fig. 3 Formation rates of (a) C2+ hydrocarbon and (b) C2+ olefins as a function of P C O 2 / P C O 2 pressure ratio during CO2 -CO-H2 reactions at 593 K over the Na/FeZn catalyst at a wide range of GHSV (8000–500000 cm3 gcat −1 h−1), CO (0–150 kPa), CO2 (93.75–225 kPa) and H2 (140–900 kPa). Fig. 4 (a) In-situ XRD patterns (593 K, 100 kPa total pressure, 37.5 kPa H2, 12.5 kPa CO2, 0–10 kPa CO, GHSV = 300000 cm3 gcat −1 h−1), (b) the relative ratios of FeCx /FeOy and (c) 57 Fe- Mӧssbauer spectra (593 K, 1500 kPa total pressure, 562.5 kPa H2, 187.5 kPa CO2, 0–150 kPa CO, balanced by Ar, GHSV = 300000 cm3 gcat −1 h−1) of the Na/FeZn catalyst after CO2 -CO-H2 reactions at different operating P C O 2 / P C O 2 pressure ratios. Fig. 5 (a) In-situ XPS spectra of Fe 2p region, (b) the surface fraction ratio of Fe species and (c) the ratios of FeCx /FeOy in Fe 2p region, and (d) in-situ XPS spectra of C 1s region, (e) the surface fraction ratio of carbon species and (f) the ratio of Carbide/Graphite in C 1s region for the Na/FeZn catalyst during CO2 hydrogenation under different P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratios for 10 h (593 K, 1500 kPa total pressure, 562.5 kPa H2, 187.5 kPa CO2, 0–150 kPa CO, balanced by Ar, 300000 cm3 gcat −1 h−1). Fig. 6 CO2-TPO profiles (CO2 consumption (a) and CO formation (b)) on the Na/FeZn catalysts after CO2-CO-H2 reactions (593 K; 562.5 kPa H2, 187.5 kPa CO2, 0–150 kPa CO, 300000 cm3 gcat −1 h−1), (c) the amounts of iron carbides (FeCx) and amorphous carbon species, per total amount of Fe atoms, and the ratio of iron carbides to amorphous carbon as functions of the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio. (d) In-situ XRD patterns, (e) Raman spectra, and (f) the ID /IG ratio of the reacted Na/FeZn catalyst (593 K, 562.5 kPa H2, 187.5 kPa CO2, 37.5 kPa CO, 300000 cm3 gcat −1 h−1, 10 h) during CO2 -TPO. Fig. 7 (a) In-situ Raman spectra of the Na/FeZn catalyst during CO2 hydrogenation at 593 K for 10 h and (b) the calculated ID /IG ratios plotted as a function of the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio. (593 K, 1500 kPa total pressure, 562.5 kPa H2, 187.5 kPa CO2, 0–150 kPa CO, balanced by Ar, 300000 cm3 gcat −1 h−1), (c) TEM images and EDX elemental maps of (d) Fe, C, and Zn, (e) C and Fe, (f) C, (g) Fe, and (h) Zn of the reacted Na/FeZn catalyst (593 K, 562.5 kPa H2, 187.5 kPa CO2, 100 kPa CO, 300000 cm3 gcat −1 h−1). State Key Laboratory of Coking Coal Resources Green Exploitation Zhengzhou University Zhengzhou 450001 China Graphical abstract This study unravels gas-driven structural and chemical dynamics of Fe clusters in a Fe-Zn catalyst during the hydrogenation of CO2, using kinetics, chemical titration, and in-situ spectroscopic characterizations. The gas-driven dynamics of iron clusters lead to a promotion in formation rates of C2+ hydrocarbons and C2+ olefins by almost one magnitude, in response to the changes in reactants. These rates are single-valued functions of the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio which determines the carbon chemical potential at the catalyst surface and influences the thermodynamic tendency for carbon deposition and carbonization of iron species. As the ratio increases, both the quantities of carbon species and iron carbides rise, however, crystalline graphite grows faster and covers part of iron carbide species at higher P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratios. These gas-driven structural dynamics allow the maximum formation of exposed iron carbide species for the formation of C2+ hydrocarbons and result in a volcano-type relationship between these formation rates and the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio. Keywords Reactant-driven structural reconstruction Hydrogenation Fe-based catalysts Carbon chemical potential Carbonization of Fe species Carbon deposition Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The development of nanoparticles with controlled size, composition, and structure opens enormous possibilities for heterogeneous catalysts with enhanced activity and selectivity. Typically, these nanoparticles are stable under vacuum or inert atmosphere. However, they undergo dynamic rearrangements in response to changes in the chemical potential of their contacting environments, as they attempt to minimize the overall Gibbs free energy, thus causing drastic transitions in shapes [1,2], compositions [3], chemical state [4–6], and for the extreme cases, bulk phase transition and elemental segregations [7,8]. These rearrangements in both bulks and surfaces cause remarkable catalytic consequences and changes in reactivities and reaction pathways, as recently recognized and manifested in catalytic oxidation [9,10], hydrodesulfurization [11], and hydrogenation [5,12]. Fe-based catalysts have emerged as an active and selective alternative for the hydrogenation of CO2 into value-added hydrocarbons, serving as a vital platform reaction for utilizing CO2 resources. This reaction generally follows a two-step pathway that combines the reverse water–gas-shift to generate CO and Fisher-Tropsch synthesis over iron oxides and iron carbides, respectively [13]. CO2 methanation, also known as the Sabatier reaction, is the main undesired reaction during CO2 hydrogenation over Fe-based catalysts. Therefore, tuning the structure of Fe-based catalysts to enhance the formation rates and selectivity of the targeted hydrocarbon remains a subject of intense research in heterogeneous catalysis. Numerous works have attempted to add secondary elements as either structural promoters or electronic promoters to modify the morphology, crystal phase, and surface properties of Fe-based catalysts. Doping alkali metal atoms, e.g., Li [14], K [14–16], Na [14,15,17–21], Rb [15], and Cs [14,15], usually enhances the surface basicity, which modifies the process of the carbonization of Fe species and inhibits the oxidation of iron carbides during catalysis. The introduction of transition metals or oxides was also widely employed to optimize the structure of Fe-based catalysts by improving the reduction of Fe2O3 (MnO2 [19,22,23], Zn [24–26]), weakening the interaction between Fe species and supports (CeO2 [27]), increasing the specific surface area of Fe species (Cu [28]), and altering their interactions with reactive intermediates. In particular, the structure of Fe-based catalysts was also affected by their synthesis methods [29,30], the conditions of pretreatment [31,32], and the properties of supports (SiO2, Al2O3, TiO2, ZrO2, porous carbon, and carbon nanotubes [14,33–35]). However, under realistic conditions of CO2 hydrogenation, the structure of Fe species in Fe-based catalysts is complex, including iron oxides (Fe2O3, Fe3O4, and FeO), metallic iron, and iron carbides (ε-Fe2C, ε′-Fe2.2C, Fe7C3, χ-Fe5C2, and θ-Fe3C) [36–38]. Moreover, different components of Fe species will undergo dynamic transformation with changes in temperature, pressure, and chemical potential. Recently, it has been widely acknowledged through in-situ spectroscopic studies that the structure and identity of Fe-based catalysts depend on their contacting environments during both the activation and reaction processes [38]. In a reducing gas atmosphere, Fe species tend to form metallic iron in H2 or iron carbides in CO, respectively [32,36,39–41]. In the presence of H2O and/or CO2, the iron carbides in both the surface and bulk phase of Fe-based catalysts undergo oxidation and transform into iron oxides [26,32,42]. These dynamic rearrangements in the structures of Fe species could cause marked catalytic consequences on CO2 hydrogenation and bring challenges to the modulation of the structure of Fe-based catalysts with high activity for hydrocarbon formation. However, most studies have focused on characterizing these Fe-based catalysts either in an inert atmosphere or in a steady-state with an unchanging composition of reactants. Under such conditions, Fe-based catalysts preserve their shapes and structures in a pristine state because the thermodynamic driving force for such transitions is virtually non-existent. In this state, Fe-based catalysts could not reconstruct as they do during catalytic turnovers. Herein, we demonstrate the structural dynamics of a Fe-based catalyst and its catalytic consequences during the hydrogenation of CO2, carried out over a wide range of reaction conditions leading to the atomistic rearrangements and even bulk phase transition with combined kinetic, quantitative chemical titrations, and in-situ spectroscopy studies. We explored that the concomitantly occurred reverse water-gas-shift (RWGS) reaction approaches chemical equilibrium, and thus, CO hydrogenation becomes kinetical relevant steps for the formation of both C2+ olefins and C2+ hydrocarbons during CO2 hydrogenation. The formation rates of C2+ hydrocarbons or C2+ olefins vary strictly with the operating P C O 2 / P C O 2 pressure ratio, because the ratio determines the carbon chemical potential at the Fe-based catalyst surface and thus the thermodynamic tendency for carbon deposition and carbonization of Fe species. The amounts of both the carbon species and iron carbides increase with increasing the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio, but the crystalline graphite grows more significantly at high P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratios regime, covering the active phase of iron carbides for the formation of C2+ hydrocarbon. These gas-driven structural evolutions result in the formation rates of C2+ hydrocarbon initially increasing to a maximum value before decreasing with increasing the operating P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio in a volcano-type relation. These gas-driven promotional changes in rate are also found during the hydrogenation of CO2 to CH3OH over Cu/ZnO catalysts [6], they reflect how the chemical potential of reactants and products determines the thermodynamic property at catalytic surfaces and thus the relative abundance of active sites during catalysis. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Synthesis of Fe-based catalyst The Fe-based catalyst (Na/FeZn, with molar ratios of Na:Fe:Zn being 0.09:2:1) was synthesized through co-precipitation and incipient wetness impregnation. Stoichiometric quantity of FeCl2·4H2O (Aladdin, 99 %) and Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O (Aladdin, 99.99 %) were dissolved in doubly deionized water (>18.2 MΩ, 200 cm3) under continuous stirring at 298 K. An aqueous solution of Na2CO3 (Aladdin, 99.99 %, 0.1 M Na+, 600 cm3) was added dropwise to the mixed solution (0.04 M Fe2+ and 0.02 M Zn2+) at a rate of 0.03 cm3 s−1 until the pH value reached to 9.0. The precipitate was separated by centrifugation and then thoroughly washed with double deionized water (>18.2 MΩ, > 15 dm3) to remove residual Na+ ions. The concentration of residual Na+ ions in the eluted solution was detected using an inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Shimadzu ICP-9820). The resulting solid samples were dried at 313 K in ambient air for over 24 h, subsequently crushed, and sieved to retain 0–75 μm particles. The solid powders were treated in ambient air at 673 K (ramping rate of 0.03 K/s) for 4 h to form a precursor (Fe2O3-ZnO) of the Fe-based catalyst. The Na/FeZn catalyst was prepared by impregnating the Fe2O3-ZnO with an aqueous solution of sodium nitrate (NaNO3, Greagent, >99 %) dissolved in doubly deionized water (>18.2 MΩ). The impregnated samples were kept at ambient temperature for over 12 h and then treated in ambient air at 333 K for over 24 h. The samples were subsequently treated in flowing dry air (Jining Xie Li Special Gas Co., Ltd., ≥99.9 %) by increasing the temperature at a ramping rate of 0.03 K/s to and holding isothermally at 673 K for 4 h. The Na/FeZn catalyst powders were pressed into pellets and sieved to retain 150–250 μm particles. 2.2 Catalytic rates and selectivity measurements. The Na/FeZn catalyst was physically mixed with quartz sand (Greagent, >99 %, 150–250 μm) at a weight ratio of 1:1 to avoid transport corruptions. The catalyst and diluent mixtures were placed between plugs of quartz wool (Titan, 4–10 μm) to form a packed catalyst bed in a quartz tube plug flow reactor (4.0 mm ID) inside a stainless-steel reactor. The quartz reactor was equipped with a K-type thermocouple (Omega, KMQXL-016G-12) placed at the center of the packed catalyst bed. The catalyst was pretreated in-situ under flowing H2 (Jining Xie Li Special Gas Co., Ltd., ≥99.9 %, 0.5 cm3 s−1) at a constant heating rate of 0.05 K/s, reaching 623 K and held for 5 h, and then cooled to 593 K under an Ar flow (Jining Xie Li Special Gas Co., Ltd., ≥99.999 %, 1.67 cm3 s−1) and simultaneously pressurized to 1500 kPa before exposure to reactants. Reactants were prepared from metering Ar, H2, CO2/Ar (Zezhong Technology Co., Ltd., 25 % CO2), and CO (Jining XieLi Special Gas Co., Ltd., ≥99.99 %) independently with thermal mass flow controllers (Brooks Instrument, SLA5850s). The pressures at the inlet and outlet of the stainless-steel reactor were measured by high-pressure transducers (MKS, 750C) and controlled by a back-pressure regulator (Equilibar, ZL1) equipped with a stainless-steel diaphragm. All transfer gas lines after the reactor were heated to 523 K to prevent the condensation of products. Two parallel connected on-line gas chromatographs quantified all reactants and products. One gas chromatograph (Shanghai Rui Min Instruments GC 2060) equipped with a TDX-01 packed column connected to a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) to quantify the concentration of H2, CO and CO2 and a Pora -PLOT-Q capillary column (Agilent J&W, CP7551. 25 m × 0.32 mm × 10.00 μm) connected to a flame ionization detector (FID) to quantify the concentration of C1-C8 hydrocarbon products. Another one (Agilent 7890B) was equipped with an Elite-5MS capillary column (PerkinElmer, N9316282, 30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm) connected to a flame ionization detector (FID) for quantifying the concentration of C7-C20 hydrocarbon products. The C7-C20 hydrocarbons were identified using an online gas chromatograph-mass spectrometer (PerkinElmer) equipped with an Elite-5MS capillary column (PerkinElmer, N9316282, 30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm) connected to a mass selective detector. The conversion rate of species i (r i, i = CO2, H2, or CO) was determined from the difference between the inlet and outlet molar flow rates of species i (F i and F i,out) normalized by the total amount of Fe atoms (n Fe) in the catalyst (Eq. (1)): (1) r i = F i - F i , o u t n F e The formation rate of carbon-containing product j (r j, j = CO, CH4, olefins, C2+ paraffins or iso-hydrocarbons) was calculated based on the carbon molar flow rate of carbon-containing product j ( F j is the molar flow rate of carbon-containing species j at the outlet of the reactor, and ν j is the carbon number of carbon-containing species j) per total amount of Fe atoms in the catalyst (Eq. (2)): (2) r j = υ j × F j n F e The reverse water–gas-shift (RWGS, Eq. (3)) reaction usually occurs simultaneously during CO2-H2 reactions and leads to CO formation. An approach-to-equilibrium value (η RWGS) was defined to quantify the extent to which the RWGS reaction approaches chemical equilibrium during catalysis (Eq. (4)) [1]: (3) CO 2 + H 2 = CO + H 2 O , Δ H ( 298 K ) = 41 kJ mol - 1 (4) η R W G S = P C O P H 2 O P C O 2 P H 2 1 K R W G S Where P r is the partial pressure of species r (r = CO, H2O, CO2 or H2) and, K RWGS is the chemical equilibrium constants for the RWGS reactions. The molar flow rate of H2O is calculated by closing the oxygen balance between reactants and products. 2.3 Characterization The composition of the as-synthesized Na/FeZn catalyst was determined by an ICP-OES (Shimadzu ICPE-9820). Before measurements, the sample was dissolved entirely in an aqueous nitric acid solution at ambient temperature. In-situ X-ray diffraction (in-situ XRD) experiments were conducted using a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray powder diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 1.5418 Å), operating at a tube voltage and current of 40 kV and 40 mA, respectively. The XRD patterns were collected with a scanning step size of 0.02° s−1 across a 2θ range of 10-80°. The Na/FeZn catalyst was finely ground and placed in a ceramic sample holder (ID: 10 mm), then treated in a H2 flow (0.83 cm3 s−1) at 623 K (heating rate 0.05 K/s) for 5 h and cooled to a reaction temperature of 593 K under flowing Ar (0.83 cm3 s−1) before exposure to CO2-CO-H2 mixtures (0.5 cm3 s−1) for 10 h. TEM images were obtained using a FEI Talos F200S transmission electron microscope (an acceleration voltage of 200 kV with a probe size of 80 pm and a probe current of ∼100 pA, cold field emission gun) equipped with an annular dark-field (ADF) detector and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy. The Na/FeZn catalyst powders were dispersed onto a holey-carbon film supported on 300 mesh Cu TEM grid (Bhaddaji-tech (Beijing) Co., Ltd.). The TEM imaging process and nanoparticle size analysis were carried out using Gatan Digital Micrograph software (Version 1.6.2) and Nano Measurer software (Version 1.2.5), respectively. In-situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (In-situ XPS) measurements were performed on a near-ambient X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy system (SPECS) equipped with a monochromatic Al-Kα source (hv = 1486.6 eV), a gas & heating reaction XPS analysis chamber (up to 2.5 kPa, 1000 K), an electron analyzer (Phoibos 150), and a three-differentially pumping stage that separates the electron energy analyzer from the analysis chamber. The in-situ XPS system is also equipped with a sample preparation chamber capable of operating at pressures up to 3.0 MPa and temperatures up to 873 K, separated by a gate valve from the XPS analysis chamber. The X-ray source was set at an acceleration voltage of 15 kV and an irradiation power of 80 W. The catalyst powders were pressed onto a clean stainless-steel sample holder (2.25 cm2 stainless-steel mesh, 1 cm2 sample) and transferred directly into the sample preparation chamber, subsequently treated in a 10 % H2/Ar flow (0.83 cm3 s−1) at 623 K (0.083 K/s) for 5 h. Afterward, the catalyst sample was cooled to a reaction temperature of 593 K in an Ar flow (0.083 cm3 s−1) and then exposed to CO2-CO-H2 mixtures at 593 K and 1500 kPa for 10 h before being purged and cooled in flowing Ar to ambient temperature. The pretreated catalyst was transferred to the XPS analysis chamber under dynamic vacuum (<5.0 × 10−4 Pa) and exposed to flowing CO2-CO-H2-Ar mixtures (2.0 kPa total pressure) at 593 K. The in-situ XPS spectra of the Na/FeZn catalyst were acquired in the analysis chamber with a pass energy of 25 eV and an energy resolution of 0.05 eV. The XPS spectra were referenced to the peak at 284.6 eV attributed to C1s and deconvoluted using mixed Gaussian − Lorentzian functions. In-situ Raman spectroscopy was conducted using a Horiba LabRAM-HR Evolution Raman spectrometer equipped with a 50x telephoto objective lens, a light source of 532 nm laser (> 300 mW), and a confocal microscope (built-in mechanical confocal pinhole, spatial resolution: better than 0.5 μm laterally and 2 μm vertically). The catalyst powders were loaded in a ceramic sample holder (ID: 4.5 mm) in a high-temperature reaction chamber and pretreated in a H2 flow (0.83 cm3 s−1) at 623 K (heating ramp of 0.05 K/s) for 5 h. Subsequently, the catalyst was cooled in an Ar flow (0.5 cm3 s−1) to 573 K and exposed to CO2-CO-H2 mixtures at 593 K and 1500 kPa for 10 h. The laser intensity was adjusted to 5 % using a 532 nm laser in the 200–2000 cm−1 range. The temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) by CO2 was performed in a micro-plug-flow reactor. The Na/FeZn catalyst was treated at 623 K (0.05 K/s) in a H2 flow (0.5 cm3 s−1) for 5 h, and then cooled to 593 K under flowing Ar (0.83 cm3 s−1). The pretreated catalyst was pressurized at 593 K to 1500 kPa in flowing Ar (1.67 cm3 s−1) and subsequently exposed to CO2-CO-H2 mixtures for 2 h at 593 K before being purged at 593 K for 1 h and cooled to 303 K in flowing Ar (1.67 cm3 s−1). The catalyst was then exposed to a CO2 flow (20 % CO2/Ar, 0.83 cm3 s−1) by increasing the temperature at 0.083 K/s from 303 K to 973 K. The amounts of CO2 consumption and CO formation were quantified by an online quadrupole mass spectroscopy (Hiden analytical, HPR-20). The quantification of carbon species on the surface of the spent Na/FeZn catalyst is based on the reaction CO2 + C = 2 CO. To avoid instrumental errors, we calculated the molar amount of carbon species using both the CO production (ncarbon = 0.5 × n(CO formation)) and the difference between CO formation and CO2 consumption (ncarbon = n(CO formation) – n(CO2 comsuption)), respectively. A Topologic MFD-500A spectrometer with 57Co (Rh) as the γ-ray source was used to measure the 57Fe Mӧssbauer spectra at room temperature. Before the measurement, the Na/FeZn catalyst (20 mg) was pretreated at 623 K (0.05 K/s) in a H2 flow (0.5 cm3 s−1) for 5 h and then cooled to 593 K under an Ar flow (0.83 cm3 s−1). The pretreated catalyst was then pressurized at 593 K to 1500 kPa in an Ar flow (1.67 cm3 s−1) and exposed to CO2-CO-H2 mixtures at 593 K for 10 h. All the spectra were fitted using the Mӧsswinn 4.0 program to determine parameters such as isomer shift (IS) and quadrupole splitting (QS). The IS values and Doppler velocities were calibrated using an α-Fe foil. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties of the Na/FeZn catalyst The molar fraction of Na, Fe, and Zn in the as-synthesized Na/FeZn catalyst was 3.3 %, 66.5 %, and 30.2 %. The BET surface area of the as-synthesized catalyst was 55.7 m2/g. The XRD pattern for the fresh Na/FeZn catalyst shows the characteristic diffractions of zinc ferrite (Fig. 1 a, ZnFe2O4, PDF 22–1012) as the dominant phase with an average crystalline size of 9.3 ± 2.0 nm. The typical peaks at 343 cm−1 (F2g(2)), 488 cm−1 (F2g(3)), and 651 cm−1 (A1g) in Raman spectra of the fresh Na/FeZn catalyst were assigned to the ZnFe2O4 phase (Fig. 1b) [43], and additional peaks at 1122 cm−1 and 1315 cm−1 attribute to Fe2O3 [44]. STEM images of the fresh Na/FeZn catalyst (Fig. 1c) show an average particle size of 10.2 ± 1.0 nm with the lattice spacing of ZnFe2O4 (311) of 0.255 nm (Fig. 1d) [45]. The corresponding EDX maps revealed uniform elemental distributions of Na, Fe, and Zn (Fig. 1f-1i). After exposure to a H2 flow at 623 K for 5 h, the zinc ferrite component was decomposed to a mixture of ZnO (PDF 79–0208, crystalline size: 15.7 ± 3.0 nm), FeO (PDF 74–1886, crystalline size: 20.4 ± 2.0 nm) and Fe (PDF 06–0696, crystalline size: 24.3 ± 2.0 nm) (Fig. 1a). The in-situ Raman spectra of the fresh Na/FeZn catalyst also indicated these characteristic peaks of both ZnFe2O4 and Fe2O3 gradually disappear during H2 pretreatment (Fig. 1b). 3.2 Formation rates of C2+ hydrocarbon and olefins are single-valued function of P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio CO2-H2 reaction yielded CO, CH4, C2+ paraffins and C2+ olefins as major carbon-containing products at a wide range of gas hourly space velocity (2.1 × 104-2.6 × 107 cm3 gcat − 1h−1) over Na/FeZn catalyst at 593 K (carbon balance of 95 ± 5 %, Fig. S1). The conversion rate of CO2 (rCO 2, per total amount of Fe atoms) and formation rates of carbon-containing products (r j, j = CO, CH4, olefins or C2+ paraffins, per total amount of Fe atoms) during CO2 hydrogenation were measured over a broad range of reaction conditions (93.75–187.5 kPa CO2, 562.5–900 kPa H2 and 0–150 kPa CO) over the Na/FeZn catalyst at 593 K and 1.5 MPa (Figs. S3-S6), attained after reaching steady-state (10 h) at each reaction condition, during which the changes in rates were less than 5 % of their respective values. The reactivity of the catalyst was routinely checked at a specific reference condition (1.5 MPa, 187.5 kPa CO2, 562.5 kPa H2; 593 K; 3 × 105 cm3 gcat −1h−1) before and after each set of rate measurements, where the difference in rates was less than 5 % before and after each rate measurement (10 h) under all conditions used in this study (Fig. S7). The hydrogenation of CO2 is considered as a combination of the RWGS reaction and the Fisher-Tropsch synthesis, which led us to explore the equilibrium position of the RWGS reaction (Eq. (3)). The approach-to-equilibrium value (η RWGS, Eq. (4)), defined as the ratio of the reaction quotient of the RWGS reaction to its equilibrium constant, approaches unity (1.0 ± 0.2, Fig. S8) during CO2-H2 reactions (GHSV of 8000–500000 cm3 gcat −1h−1, 562.5 kPa H2 and 187.5 kPa CO2) at 593 K, confirming that the RWGS reaction reaches chemical equilibrium. Co-feeding CO (0–150 kPa, Fig. S8) into CO2-H2 reactants (562.5–900 kPa H2 and 93.75–187.5 kPa CO2) did not disrupt the equilibrated feature of the RWGS reaction. Under the conditions at the equilibrium of the RWGS reaction, all elementary steps within the catalytic RWGS path cycle, i.e., those associated with the activation of CO2 and H2 and the formation of CO and H2O, must all be in a state of equilibrium. This implies that the interconversion of CO2 and CO is significantly more efficient than the sequential hydrogenation, and thus provides carbon sources in an equilibrated chemical pool for producing CH4, C2+ olefins, and C2+ paraffins. Fig. 2 shows the formation rates of C2+ hydrocarbons and C2+ olefins during CO2-CO-H2 reactions over the Na/FeZn catalyst at 593 K. The effective reaction orders with respect to H2 are nearly two for the formation of C2+ hydrocarbons (1.75 ± 0.20, Figs. 2a and S9a) and C2+ olefins (1.67 ± 0.20, Figs. 2b and S9c), and with respect to CO2 are less than one for C2+ hydrocarbons (0.85 ± 0.20, Figs. 2c and S9b) and C2+ olefins formation (0.67 ± 0.20, Figs. 2d and S9d). However, these rates initially increased to maximum values and then decreased with increasing CO pressure (0–150 kPa, Fig. 2c and 2f) during CO2-CO-H2 reactions. These apparent complex rate-dependencies (Figs. 2 and S1) of CO2-CO-H2 reactions, however, can be captured by simply correlating the formation rates of either C2+ hydrocarbons (Fig. 3 a, the summation of C2+ olefins, C2+ paraffins, and iso-hydrocarbon) or C2+ olefins (Fig. 3b) to the operating P C O 2 / P C O 2 pressure ratio. The formation rates of C2+ hydrocarbons or C2+ olefins are single-valued functions of the operating P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio, irrespective of the individual pressures of H2 (140–750 kPa), CO2 (93.75–225 kPa), and CO (0–150 kPa) and the space velocity of CO2-H2 reactants (8000–500000 cm3 gcat −1h−1): (5) r j = f P CO 2 P CO 2 The formation rates of both C2+ hydrocarbons and C2+ olefins increased with increasing the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio to a maximum value at a P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio of 0.3 and then decreased sharply until the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio reached about 2. The dependence of these formation rates on the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio led us to consider whether this ratio prescribes the identity of the Na/FeZn catalyst and, in turn, the active sites and their rates. The interconversion between CO and CO2 may also occur concomitantly via the exothermic Boudouard reaction (2CO = C + CO2, ΔH(298 K) = − 172 kJ/mol, Eq. S14) during CO2-CO-H2 reactions over Fe-based catalysts. The disproportionation of CO leads to CO2 formation and leaves behind a carbon (C*) on the Fe-based catalyst surface (2CO = C + CO2, C + [*] → [C*]; [*] and [C*] represent the concentration of unoccupied sites and surface carbon atoms, Eq. S15). Therefore, the P C O 2 / P C O 2 pressure ratio determines the ratio of the surface carbon-to-unoccupied site, [C*]-to-[*], with the assumption of the equilibrated interconversion between gas species: (6) [ C ∗ ] [ ∗ ] = K S 14 K S 15 P C O 2 P θ P C O 2 Where K S8 and K S9 refer to the equilibrium constant of the interconversion between CO and CO2 via the Boudouard reaction (Eq. S14) and the rate constant of the deposition of carbon (Eq. S15); P θ refers to the standard pressure. The [C*]-to-[*] ratio directly reflects the carbon chemical potential at the catalyst surface and, thus, is a rigorous surrogate of the carbon coverages and the thermodynamic activity of carbon at catalyst surfaces during CO2-CO-H2 reactions. The carbon chemical potential and the identity of C* and unoccupied sites (*) are expected to differ on these metallic irons, iron oxides, and iron carbides in Fe-based catalysts during CO2 hydrogenation due to different binding strengths of surface C*. The changing the P C O 2 / P C O 2 pressure ratio may change the surface properties of the catalyst and the thermodynamically stable phase of the Fe catalyst during steady-state catalysis, and in turn, dictating the nature and availability of active sites for the formation of C2+ hydrocarbons and C2+ olefins from CO2-CO-H2 reactions. Next, we systematically tuned the P C O 2 / P C O 2 pressure ratio and explored the structure of the Fe-based catalyst under realistic working conditions. 3.3 Reactants-Driven dynamic of the working Na/FeZn catalyst during CO2-CO-H2 reaction. The in-situ XRD patterns show that the bulk phase of the Na/FeZn catalyst becomes a mixture of ZnO (PDF 79–0208), Fe3O4 (PDF 19–0629), χ-Fe5C2 (PDF 36–1248), and θ-Fe3C (PDF 65–2413) after being exposed to CO2-CO-H2 mixtures (Fig. 4 a) at 593 K. The iron oxides (Fe2O3, Fe3O4, and FeO), metallic iron, and iron carbides (ε-Fe2C, ε′-Fe2.2C, Fe7C3, χ-Fe5C2, and θ-Fe3C) were also reported to be coexisted during the hydrogenation of CO or CO2 [36–38]. These iron carbides, especially the χ-Fe5C2 and θ-Fe3C phases, were proposed as active phases for forming C2+ hydrocarbon from the hydrogenation of CO or CO2 [21,36,38,46–49]. In this work, the relative amounts of iron carbides (χ-Fe5C2 and θ-Fe3C) and iron oxides (Fe3O4) were determined by the characteristic reflection of 100 % intensity in the Powder Diffraction File (PDF) through a Reference Intensity Ratio (RIR) method. The average crystalline size of ZnO, Fe3O4, χ-Fe5C2, and θ-Fe3C was 19.7 ± 2.0 nm, 20.2 ± 3.0 nm, 20.7 ± 2.0 nm, and 17.4 ± 2.0 nm during CO2-CO-H2 reactions at 593 K, respectively, irrespective to the values of the P C O 2 / P C O 2 pressure ratio (0.02–1.13, Fig. 4a). However, the intensity of iron oxides (Fe3O4) decreased while those of iron carbides (Fe5C2 and θ-Fe3C) increased with increasing the operating P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio (Fig. 4a), and thus the relative ratio of FeCx/FeOy in the Na/FeZn catalyst increased sharply with increasing the ratio (Fig. 4b). These phase transitions between iron oxides and iron carbides are probably caused by that the increasing P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio leads to a lower oxygen chemical potential (K OPCO2 P CO −1, Eq. S12, determined by the equilibrated RWGS reaction) and a higher carbon chemical potential (K C(P CO)2 P CO2 −1(P θ)−1, Eq. (6)), and thus enhancing the thermodynamic driving force for preventing the phase oxidation of iron carbides and promoting the carbonization of iron oxides. These dynamic phase transitions between Fe species in the Na/FeZn catalysts were also quantitatively analyzed by Mӧssbauer spectroscopy. Fig. 4c and Table 1 show the Mӧssbauer spectrum and the deconvoluted sub-spectrum of the spent Na/FeZn catalysts after exposure to CO2-CO-H2 mixtures with different P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratios at 593 K for 20 h. The patterns were fitted with six sextets, representing χ-Fe5C2, θ-Fe3C, Fe0, and doublet (Fe3O4). In detail, three sextets with magnetic hyperfine fields (H) of 21.6, 18.6, and 10.8 T can be assigned to three different sites of stoichiometric χ-Fe5C2 while another sextet signal at 20.2 T with the IS values of 0.17–0.21 mm s−1 can be ascribed to the cubic site of θ-Fe3C [50,51]. The sextet with magnetic hyperfine fields (H) of 32.9 T is attributed to Fe0 species [52]. The spectra of the Na/FeZn catalyst contain doublet (Fe3O4), which are characteristic of superparamagnetic Fe(II) or Fe(III) species [53], indicating highly dispersed iron oxides (Fe3O4) species. The isomer shift (IS) and quadrupole splitting (QS) of the doublet (Fe3O4) were 0.13–0.21 mm s−1 and 0.89–1.00 mm s−1, respectively, indicating the existence of trivalent iron oxide species [53]. When exposed to CO2-CO-H2 mixtures with a low P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio of 0.02, the Na/FeZn catalyst comprised three predominant Fe phases, namely θ-Fe3C (55.38 %), Fe0 (37.75 %), and doublet (Fe3O4, 6.87 %). The content of doublet (Fe3O4) in the Na/FeZn catalyst exhibited insensitively to the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio within the CO2-CO-H2 mixtures and remained within a value range of 6.87 % to 8.54 %. Previous DFT calculations indicate that the carburization of Fe3O4 is extremely difficult due to the high barrier for a carbon atom permeating and carburizing the Fe3O4 interlayer [54]. As the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio increased, the fraction of both the Fe0 and θ-Fe3C phases decreased. Conversely, the total fraction of the three χ-Fe5C2 phases increased to 83.78 % at the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio of 1.1. Hence, increasing the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio promotes the formation of a carbon-rich χ-Fe5C2 phase in the Na/FeZn catalyst during the CO2-CO-H2 reaction. These dynamic transitions in the chemical state and the atomic fraction of elements in the Na/FeZn catalyst during the CO2-CO-H2 reaction at 593 K were measured by in-situ XPS. During CO2-CO-H2 reactions, the chemical state of Zn in the Na/FeZn catalyst remained as Zn2+, insensitive to the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio, as evidenced by the XPS spectra of the Zn 2p and Zn LMM regions (Fig. S11). Fig. 5 a presents the XPS spectrum in the Fe 2p region for the Na/FeZn catalyst during CO2-CO-H2 reactions at 593 K and different P C O 2 / P C O 2 pressure ratios. Deconvolution of the Fe 2p signals reveals three chemical states of Fe species in the surface layers of the Na/FeZn catalyst (Table S2). Fe 2p signals at ∼ 709.4 eV and ∼ 711.2 eV, along with their satellite signals (Fe 2p1/2) at ∼ 722.5 and ∼ 724.3 eV, indicate the coexistence of Fe2+ and Fe3+ species in the surface layers of the Na/FeZn catalyst [55]. The binding energies (BEs) at ∼707.2 and ∼720.3 eV were assigned to Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 of FeCx [21,26,52,56]. The atomic fraction of Fe2+ and Fe3+ species, determined from the area ratio in Fe 2p signals, both decreased from 36.14 % and 13.07 % to approximately 31 % and 5 %, respectively, as the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio in the CO2-CO-H2 mixtures increased. In contrast, the atomic fraction of FeCx species demonstrated a significant increase, rising from 50.79 % to 62.93 % as the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio increased (Fig. 5b). As a result, the FeCx/FeOy ratio increased from 1.03 to 1.70 with an increase in the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio (Fig. 5c), indicating that higher P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio reaction conditions also favor the phase transition of iron oxides to iron carbides in the surface layers of the Na/FeZn catalyst. Fig. 5d shows the C 1s XPS spectra of the Na/FeZn catalyst and their corresponding deconvoluted results during CO2-CO-H2 reactions at 593 K and different P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratios. The spectrum deconvolution reveals the C 1s signals at 283.6, 284.6, 285.8, and 289.7 eV, and could be assigned to the carbide species, carbon in graphite, C–C bonds in hydrocarbons, and carbon–oxygen double bond contained species, respectively [22,57,58]. The graphite was the primary carbon-containing species, and its surface atomic fraction increased significantly from 31.23 % to 55.03 % with increasing the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio (Fig. 5e and Table S3). The surface atomic fractions of the rest of the carbon-containing species (carbide species, C–C bonds in hydrocarbons, and carbon–oxygen double bond contained species) all decreased slightly with increasing the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio (Fig. 5e and Table S3). Therefore, the surface atomic ratio of carbides to graphite significantly reduced from 0.45 to 0.13 (Fig. 5f) with increasing the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio, suggesting the generation of graphitic carbon is more favorable than the formation of iron carbides at high P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio region. Consequently, the carbon and oxygen chemical potential at the surfaces of the Fe-based catalyst, determined by the operating P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio in CO2-CO-H2 reactants, serves as the thermodynamic driving force for the instantaneous carbonization and oxidation of Fe species. Increasing the P C O 2 / P C O 2 pressure ratio inhibits the phase oxidation of iron carbides and drives both the generation of graphitic carbon species and the carbonization of Fe species. More importantly, the ratio promotes the formation of a carbon-rich Fe5C2 species as an active phase for forming C2+ hydrocarbons from CO2-CO-H2 reactions over the Na/FeZn catalyst. 3.4 Dynamic transition of the surface carbon-containing species on the working Na/FeZn catalyst CO2 is a weak oxidant. Temperature-programmed CO2 oxidation (CO2-TPO) was employed to quantitatively identify the types of carbon-containing species on the Na/FeZn catalyst. Fig. 6 a and 6b show the mass spectrometric (MS) profiles of the CO2-TPO conducted on the Na/FeZn catalyst after exposure to the CO2-CO-H2 reactant at 593 K for 2 h. The obtained CO2-TPO profiles exhibited two distinct oxidation peaks at 600–750 K and 800–950 K, respectively. Fig. 6d and 6e present the in-situ XRD patterns and in-situ Raman spectra of the Na/FeZn catalyst during CO2-TPO. The FeCx phase is the predominant phase in the Na/FeZn catalyst after being exposed to CO2-CO-H2 reactants (562.5 kPa H2, 187.5 kPa CO2; P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio of 0.02–1.13) at 593 K. During CO2-TPO experiments, the ZnFe2O4 phase was formed via the gradual oxidation of FeCx by CO2 at the temperature above 673 K, and their intensity reached a constant value at temperature above 773 K. In the Raman spectra, two major C–C bands centered at 1334 cm−1 and 1575 cm−1 were observed on the Na/FeZn catalyst after being exposed to CO2-CO-H2 mixtures (562.5 kPa H2, 187.5 kPa CO2; P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio of 0.02–1.13) at 593 K for 10 h (Fig. 6e), representing the vibration of amorphous sp2- bonded carbon species (D band) and crystalline graphite (G band), respectively [59]. The intensity ratios of the D to G band (ID/IG ratio), in Fig. 6f, express the relative contribution of the amorphous carbon and crystalline graphite carbon on the catalysts. During CO2-TPO experiments, the ID/IG ratio maintained at a constant value (1.0 ± 0.1) as the temperature increased until it reached above 773 K, above which the ID/IG ratio decreased gradually. Combining the results of in-situ XRD and in-situ Raman, the MS profiles of CO2-TPO at 600–750 K can be assigned to the oxidation of FeCx by CO2 to form Fe2O3 and CO (2FeCx + (2x + 3) CO2 = Fe2O3 + (4x + 3) CO). The MS profiles of CO2-TPO at 800–950 K could be attributed to the thermodynamically unfavorable oxidation of the amorphous carbon species by CO2 to form gaseous CO (C + CO2 = 2CO, ΔH(298 K) = 172 kJ/mol) [60,61], while the more stable graphitic carbon was much more difficult to be oxidized by CO2 below 1000 K (Fig. S12). The amounts of FeCx and amorphous carbon species were determined by the difference between CO formation and CO2 consumption in the MS profiles of CO2-TPO (Table S4). Fig. 6c shows the amounts of FeCx and amorphous carbon species, normalized by the total amount of Fe atoms in the Na/FeZn catalyst, as functions of the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio. The amounts of both FeCx species and amorphous carbon species increased with the increasing P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio. However, the ratio of the FeCx species to amorphous carbon species decreased with the P C O 2 / P C O 2 pressure ratio. This result indicates the generation of amorphous carbon is more favorable than the formation of iron carbides in the high P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratios region, which is consistent with our above XPS results and the thermodynamic favorability of carbon formation. This is because the Gibbs free energy is more negative for carbon deposition (2CO = C + CO2, ΔG(593 K) = − 67 kJ/mol) than that for the formation of iron carbides (2CO + Fe = Fe3C + CO2, ΔG(593 K) = − 56 kJ/mol and 2CO + 2.5Fe = 0.5Fe5C2 + CO2, ΔG(593 K) = − 54 kJ/mol) [62]. The dynamic transition of these surface carbon-containing species on the working Na/FeZn catalyst was further analyzed by an in-situ Raman spectra conducted on the catalyst after being exposed to CO2-CO-H2 mixtures with different P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratios at 593 K for 10 h. Fig. 7 a shows two major C–C bands centered at 1334 cm−1 and 1575 cm−1, attributed respectively to the vibration of amorphous sp2- bonded carbon species (D band) and crystalline graphite (G band) [59]. The derived ID/IG ratio initially increased to a maximum value and then decreased with increasing the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio in Fig. 7b. The change in the ID/IG ratio suggests that the crystalline graphite carbon on the Na/FeZn catalyst grows more slowly than the amorphous carbon with increasing the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio until the ratio reaches about 0.4. Above this ratio, the amount of crystalline graphite carbon increased more significantly than the amorphous carbon. The formation of a large amount of surface carbon, especially crystalline graphite carbon, may prevent the diffusion of reactants and products and even occupy the active phase of iron carbides for hydrocarbon formation. Fig. 7c-7 h show TEM image and EDX elemental maps of the Na/FeZn catalyst, taken after the exposure to CO2-CO-H2 mixture (562.5 kPa H2, 187.5 kPa CO2, 100 kPa CO; 300000 cm3 gcat −1h−1) at 593 K. These micrograph shows the Fe species in the Na/FeZn catalyst were covered with carbon-contained species. 3.5 The reactant-driven structure-performance relationship of the Fe-based catalyst for forming C2+ hydrocarbons In Fe-based catalysts, iron carbides, especially the χ-Fe5C2 phase, are commonly accepted as the active phase for C-O bond activation and C–C bond formation during the formation of C2+ hydrocarbons from the hydrogenation of CO2 or CO [21,36,38,46,47,63]. The iron oxides are proposed to be the active phase for the reverse water-gas-shift reaction during CO2 hydrogenation [64–66]. In this study, the kinetic dependence indicates that the RWGS reaction reaches thermodynamic equilibrium, and the formation rates of hydrocarbons are limited by CO hydrogenation during the CO2-CO-H2 reaction. Therefore, the formation rates of hydrocarbons may be related to the amount of iron carbides in the Na/FeZn catalyst. The formation rates of C2+ hydrocarbons are functions of the operating P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio, and thus, we next explore the formation rates of C2+ hydrocarbons versus the structure of Fe-based catalyst obtained under CO2-CO-H2 mixtures at different P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratios by a series of in-situ spectroscopies and chemical titrations. Fig. 8 a and 8b show the formation rate of C2+ hydrocarbons as functions of the bulk ratio of FeCx-to-FeOy (in-situ XRD) and the surface ratio of FeCx-to-FeOy (in-situ XPS) in the Na/FeZn catalyst. At low operating P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratios below 0.4, the formation rates of C2+ hydrocarbon increased proportionally with the ratio of FeCx-to-FeOy in both the surface layer and bulk phase of the catalyst, consistent with the general hypothesis that iron carbides are active phases for producing C2+ hydrocarbon. However, the formation rates of C2+ hydrocarbon started to decrease sharply by further increasing the FeCx-to-FeOy ratio in both the bulk phase and surface layers of the catalyst. We noticed that increasing the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratios also drives the carbon deposition on the catalyst, and the rates of carbon deposition rise more significantly than those of the formation of iron carbides with increasing the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio, and thus considered connecting the formation rates of C2+ hydrocarbons with the identity of surface carbon species. Fig. 8c shows the rates of hydrocarbons versus the ratio of the crystalline graphite to the amorphous carbon species (IG/ID). The rates of C2+ hydrocarbons decreased sharply with increasing the IG/ID ratio in the range of 0.5 to 1.5, indicating that the crystalline graphite covers and occupies the active iron carbides for the formation of C2+ hydrocarbons. As results, increasing the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio in the mixtures of CO2-CO-H2 increases the carbon chemical potential at the catalyst surface, and thus enhances the thermodynamic tendency for carbon deposition and carbonization of Fe species to form active iron carbides, the crystalline graphite covers the surface of iron carbides (Fig. 7c), and finally leading the formation rates of C2+ hydrocarbon vary with the operating P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio in a volcano-type relation. 4 Conclusions Kinetic rate measurements, in-situ spectroscopies, and chemical titration experiments were used to reveal the structural and chemical dynamics of a Fe-based catalyst and its catalytic consequences on the hydrogenation of CO2. During CO2 hydrogenation over the Na/FeZn catalyst, the concomitantly occurred reverse water–gas-shift (RWGS) reaction approaches chemical equilibrium. The equilibrated interconversion between CO2 and CO provides carbon sources in a “chemical pool” for producing CH4, C2+ olefins, and C2+ paraffins. The formation rates of both C2+ hydrocarbons and C2+ olefins varied strictly with the operating P C O 2 / P C O 2 pressure ratio, irrespective to the individual CO2, CO, and H2 pressures. These rates increased to a maximum value as the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio increased from 0.02 to 0.4, but decreased as the ratio exceeded 0.4. These pressure ratios determine the carbon chemical potential at the catalyst surface via the Boudouard reaction and, thus, the thermodynamically stable structure of the Fe-based catalyst during steady-state catalysis. Under realistic working conditions of CO2-CO-H2, the fraction of iron carbides in both the bulk phase and surface layers increases with increasing the operating P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratios. The amounts of both the crystalline graphite and the amorphous carbon species also increase more significantly with increasing the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio than that of iron carbides. These structural evolutions, in response to changes in the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio, enhance the formation of the active phase of iron carbides in the catalyst for producing C2+ hydrocarbon, but lead the iron carbides to be covered by crystalline graphite at high P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratios regime, and finally resulting the formation rates of C2+ hydrocarbon vary with the operating P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio in a volcano-type relation during the CO2-CO-H2 reaction. In this work, the as-established relationship of structure-performance in the heterogenous catalysis, in the case of CO2 hydrogenation over a Fe-based catalyst using kinetics and in-situ characterization, shed deep insight into the mechanism understanding of such a complex reaction. coredata.dc:description: This study unravels gas-driven structural and chemical dynamics of Fe clusters in a Fe-Zn catalyst during the hydrogenation of CO2, using kinetics, chemical titration, and in-situ spectroscopic characterizations. The gas-driven dynamics of iron clusters lead to a promotion in formation rates of C2+ hydrocarbons and C2+ olefins by almost one magnitude, in response to the changes in reactants. These rates are single-valued functions of the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio which determines the carbon chemical potential at the catalyst surface and influences the thermodynamic tendency for carbon deposition and carbonization of iron species. As the ratio increases, both the quantities of carbon species and iron carbides rise, however, crystalline graphite grows faster and covers part of iron carbide species at higher P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratios. These gas-driven structural dynamics allow the maximum formation of exposed iron carbide species for the formation of C2+ hydrocarbons and result in a volcano-type relationship between these formation rates and the P C O 2 / P C O 2 ratio.
